text: In theory. Unless a protester/rioter wishes to see them.
author: ClaireBerlinski

text: This is all true; nonetheless, any defeat of ISIS is worth celebrating. Cautiously. We know (from bitter experience) that it isn't the end. But neither is a victory for ISIS, that's for sure. And that, for all the caveats, is cause for relief.
author: ClaireBerlinski

text: That's true too, but no amount of competence could give a small number of riot cops the ability to be everywhere at once.
author: ClaireBerlinski

text: No. They haven't because there just aren't enough of them.
author: ClaireBerlinski

text: For people who share this question, here are a few articles I've written about the way the police have responded to this crisis: https://www.the-american-interest.com/2018/12/13/france-doesnt-have-enough-cops/ … and http://braveoldworld2016.blogspot.com/2018/12/the-battle-of-etoile.html …
author: ClaireBerlinski

text: The result will tell me whether I've been right to say, "For God's sake, ****take their advice***."
author: ClaireBerlinski

text: "War is declared." Today the government will be (for the first time) using the policing strategy the police unions have been begging them to use toward the Gilets Jaunes since the crisis began.
author: ClaireBerlinski

text: Nope. That's why they fired the police chief.
author: ClaireBerlinski

text: Because there aren't, numerically, enough cops to guard the static targets so that the CRS can do their jobs properly. If he keeps deploying an undermanned, exhausted police force, he's running even more risk. It's just a miracle no one's been killed so far. They've been lucky.
author: ClaireBerlinski

text: About all that's left to say.
author: ClaireBerlinski
